sen.j: 尚泰王（しょうたいおう、1843年8月3日（道光23年7月8日） - 1901年8月19日）は、琉球王国第二尚氏王統第19代国王。
sen.e: King SHO Tai (August 3, 1843 - August 19, 1901) was a King of the Ryukyu Kingdom, the 19th of the line of the Second Sho Dynasty.
King SHO Tai (August 3, 1843 - August 19, 1901) was a King of the Ryukyu Kingdom, the 19th of the line of the Second Sho Dynasty.
King SHO Tai (August 3, 1843 - August 19, 1901) was a King of the Ryukyu Kingdom, the 19th of the line of the Second Sho Dynasty.

sen.j: 最後の国王である。
sen.e: SHO Tai was the last king.
He was the last king of the Ryukyu Kingdom.
sen.cmt: 名前の繰返しを避けるため、代名詞に修正しました。また何の最後の王か説明を加えました。
sen.e: He was the last king of the Ryukyu Kingdom.
SHO Tai ruled from 1848 to 1879.
He ruled from 1848 to 1879.
sen.cmt: 名前の繰返しを避けるため、代名詞に修正しました。
sen.e: He ruled from 1848 to 1879.

sen.j: 父は、第18代国王尚育王。
sen.e: SHO Tai's father was King SHO Iku, the 18th king of the Ryukyu Kingdom.
SHO Tai's father was King SHO Iku, the 18th king of the Ryukyu Kingdom.
SHO Tai's father was King SHO Iku, the 18th king of the Ryukyu Kingdom.

sen.j: 道光28年5月8日（1848年6月8日）にわずか4歳（数え年では6歳）にして即位。
sen.e: On June 8, 1848, SHO Tai ascended the throne at the tender age of 4 (in his 6th year).
On June 8, 1848, SHO Tai ascended the throne at the tender age of 4 (in his 6th year).
On June 8, 1848, SHO Tai ascended the throne at the tender age of 4 (in his 6th year).

sen.j: 咸豊4年（1854年）にはマシュー・ペリーが琉球に来航し琉米修好条約を締結。
sen.e: In 1854 U.S. naval officer Commodore Matthew Calbraith PERRY arrived in Ryukyu, so that a Treaty of Amity between the Ryukyu Kingdom and the United States was concluded.
In 1854 U.S. naval officer Commodore Matthew Calbraith PERRY arrived in Ryukyu, so that a Treaty of Amity between the Ryukyu Kingdom and the United States was concluded.
In 1854 U.S. naval officer Commodore Matthew Calbraith PERRY arrived in Ryukyu, so that a Treaty of Amity between the Ryukyu Kingdom and the United States was concluded.

sen.j: 1855年、琉仏修好条約を結び、1859年には琉蘭修好条約を結ぶ。
sen.e: In 1855 a Treaty of Amity was concluded between the Ryukyu Kingdom and France, which was followed by the conclusion of a Treaty of Amity between the Ryukyu Kingdom and Holland in 1859.
In 1855 a Treaty of Amity was concluded between the Ryukyu Kingdom and France, which was followed by the conclusion of a Treaty of Amity between the Ryukyu Kingdom and Holland in 1859.
In 1855 a Treaty of Amity was concluded between the Ryukyu Kingdom and France, which was followed by the conclusion of a Treaty of Amity between the Ryukyu Kingdom and Holland in 1859.

sen.j: 他府県の廃藩置県も済んだ翌年、元来琉球は日本と清（中国）に使を送り独自性を保っていたが、同治11年（1872年）に日本は強引に尚泰を琉球藩藩王に冊封し、東京に藩邸を与えられた。
sen.e: In the following year after an abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures (which is known as Haihan-chiken in Japanese), although Ryukyu had basically maintained her identity (independence) by sending missions to Japan and Qing (China), yet in 1872 Japan forced SHO Tai to be resigned to establishing a vassal relationship with Japan, and SHO Tai was thereby appointed King of the Ryukyu Han (feudal clan) and given a residence in Tokyo with the new title Han-O (king of the clan).

In the following year after an abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures (which is known as Haihan-chiken in Japanese), although Ryukyu had basically maintained her identity (independence) by sending missions to Japan and Qing (China), yet in 1872 Japan forced SHO Tai to be resigned to establishing a vassal relationship with Japan, and SHO Tai was thereby appointed King of the Ryukyu Han (feudal clan) and given a residence in Tokyo with the new title Han-O (king of the clan).

In the following year after an abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures (which is known as Haihan-chiken in Japanese), although Ryukyu had basically maintained her identity (independence) by sending missions to Japan and Qing (China), yet in 1872 Japan forced SHO Tai to be resigned to establishing a vassal relationship with Japan, and SHO Tai was thereby appointed King of the Ryukyu Han (feudal clan) and given a residence in Tokyo with the new title Han-O (king of the clan).

sen.j: 然うして光緒5年（1879年）の所謂琉球処分の断行で琉球藩に沖縄県が設置されると、王号を剥奪され居城の首里城も追われ、琉球王国は消滅した。
sen.e: Thus, in 1879 the Ryukyu Kingdom was forcibly demolished and the Okinawa Prefecture was created instead, SHO Tai was forced to abdicate and vacate the royal residence of Shuri-jo Castle, whereby the Ryukyu Kingdom disappeared.
sen.cmt: 原文で、琉球処分の前に「沖縄県の歴史」とありましたが、リンク先表示でしたので削除しました。
sen.e: Thus, in 1879 the Ryukyu Kingdom was forcibly demolished and the Okinawa Prefecture was created instead, SHO Tai was forced to abdicate and vacate the royal residence of Shuri-jo Castle, whereby the Ryukyu Kingdom disappeared.

Thus, in 1879 the Ryukyu Kingdom was forcibly demolished and the Okinawa Prefecture was created instead, SHO Tai was forced to abdicate and vacate the royal residence of Shuri-jo Castle, whereby the Ryukyu Kingdom disappeared.

sen.j: 尚泰たちは琉球王家の屋敷の一つ中城御殿に移ったが、明治政府の命により東京に移住させられる。
sen.e: SHO Tai and his courtiers moved to one of the Ryukyuan royal residences of Naka-gusuku Castle (the Nakagushiku Udun in Ryukyuan), but were displaced to a residence in Tokyo upon order of the Meiji Imperial Government.

SHO Tai and his courtiers moved to one of the Ryukyuan royal residences of Naka-gusuku Castle (the Nakagushiku Udun in Ryukyuan), but were displaced to a residence in Tokyo upon order of the Meiji Imperial Government.

SHO Tai and his courtiers moved to one of the Ryukyuan royal residences of Naka-gusuku Castle (the Nakagushiku Udun in Ryukyuan), but were displaced to a residence in Tokyo upon order of the Meiji Imperial Government.

sen.j: 尚泰の次男尚寅、四男尚順は後に沖縄に帰ってきている。
sen.e: SHO In, the second son of SHO Tai, and SHO Jun, the fourth son, returned to Okinawa in later years.
SHO In, the second son of SHO Tai, and SHO Jun, the fourth son, returned to Okinawa in later years.
SHO In, the second son of SHO Tai, and SHO Jun, the fourth son, returned to Okinawa in later years.

sen.j: のち華族令の発令に伴って侯爵となった。
sen.e: Upon announcement of Peerage Law (which is called Kazoku-rei in Japanese), SHO Tai was made Marquis.
Upon announcement of Peerage Law (which is called Kazoku-rei in Japanese), SHO Tai was made Marquis.
Upon announcement of Peerage Law (which is called Kazoku-rei in Japanese), SHO Tai was made Marquis.

sen.j: 1901年に59歳で没。
sen.e: SHO Tai died in 1901, at the age of 59.
SHO Tai died in 1901, at the age of 59.
SHO Tai died in 1901, at the age of 59.

sen.j: 墓所は沖縄県那覇市の琉球王家の陵墓・玉陵（たまうどぅん）。
sen.e: SHO Tai's body was buried in Tama-udun Royal Mausoleum of the Ryukyuan royal house, which is located in Naha City, Okinawa Prefecture.
SHO Tai's body was buried in Tama-udun Royal Mausoleum of the Ryukyuan royal house, which is located in Naha City, Okinawa Prefecture.
SHO Tai's body was buried in Tama-udun Royal Mausoleum of the Ryukyuan royal house, which is located in Naha City, Okinawa Prefecture.

sen.j: 現在も尚家の子孫は沖縄、首里に健在である。
sen.e: Still today the descendants of the Sho family live in Shuri district of Naha City, Okinawa Prefecture.
Still today the descendants of the Sho family live in Shuri district of Naha City, Okinawa Prefecture.
Still today the descendants of the Sho family live in Shuri district of Naha City, Okinawa Prefecture.

sen.j: 「命どぅ宝」は尚泰王の言葉と言われることもあるが、本来は演劇中のセリフである。
sen.e: A famous "Nuchi du Takara" (words in Ryukyuan, meaning "Life is the treasure") was once attributed to King SHO Tai, but it is originally the lines in a play.
sen.cmt: 参考（命どぅ宝の読み 「ヌチドゥタカラ」、「命こそ宝」）：http://bunbun.boo.jp/okera/nano/nuchidou_takara.htm
sen.e: A famous "Nuchi du Takara" (words in Ryukyuan, meaning "Life is the treasure") was once attributed to King SHO Tai, but it is originally the lines in a play.
A famous "Nuchi du Takara" (words in Ryukyuan, meaning "Life is the treasure") was once attributed to King SHO Tai, but it is originally the lines in a play.

sen.j: 冊封使（1866年）
sen.e: Sakuho-shi Delegates (the term sakuho refers to the Chinese emperor's acknowledgment of the status of the Ryukyu Kingdom, and the Chinese representatives dispatched by the Chinese emperor was called Sakuhoshi) (1866):

sen.j: 正使：趙新（右春坊右贊善）
sen.e: Senior envoy: CHO Shin (Zhào Xīn in Chinese) (Ushunbo Usanzen, meaning a Chamberlain of the Right to the crown prince, a member of the Board of the Crown Prince's Household of the Right)
sen.cmt: 参考：http://ryukyushimpo.jp/news/storyid-42125-storytopic-121.html 「賛善は官名。東宮侍従官」：http://www.digigi.jp/bin/showprod?c=2041017411197 「『春坊』とは太子詹事府に左右二春坊と設置され、諸局を領する、太子の宮所に所属する官署の名である。」：http://www.japanology.cn/japanese/paper/ch/12%E8%91%9B%E7%B6%99%E5%8B%87%EF%BC%88%E4%BA%95%E7%9C%9F%E6%88%90%EF%BC%89.htm

sen.e: Father: King SHO Iku
Father: King SHO Iku

sen.j: 母：元貞（尚育王妃・佐敷按司加那志）
sen.e: Mother: Gentei (queen consort to King SHO Iku, bearing the title of Sashiki-Ajiganashi, Queen of the Ryukyu Kingdom)
sen.cmt: 元貞の読み不明。元が出身氏族名かどうか不明ですので、名として扱っています。参考（尚氏系図）：http://www.geocities.co.jp/SilkRoad-Desert/3914/ryuhkyuhkeizu.html
sen.e: Mother: Gentei (queen consort to King SHO Iku, bearing the title of Sashiki-Ajiganashi, Queen of the Ryukyu Kingdom)
Mother: Gentei (queen consort to King SHO Iku, bearing the title of Sashiki-Ajiganashi, Queen of the Ryukyu Kingdom)

sen.j: 妃：章氏思真鶴金・佐敷按司加那志（号は賢室）
sen.e: Queen consort: Sho-shi Umimajirugani, Sashiki-Ajiganashi (her pseudonym is Kenshitsu, literally meaning the wise wife).
sen.cmt: 章氏思真鶴金「しょうし・うみまぢるがにー」の読みは国立国語研究所編「沖縄語辞典」の記述をもとに応用したものです。「大名（でーみょー）の童名（わらびなー）」：男子「思太郎金（うみたるがにー）」、女子「真鶴金（まぢるがにー）」。
sen.e: Queen consort: Sho-shi Umimajirugani, Sashiki-Ajiganashi (her pseudonym is Kenshitsu, literally meaning the wise wife).

sen.j: 真鶴金・松川按司（父は毛其昌・美里親方安綱）
sen.e: Majirugani: Princess (Aji or Anji or Anzu) Matsugawa (or Machigaa) (the term aji refers to the highest rank below a prince in the Ryukyu Kingdom) (her father was Mo Kisho:Misato Ueekata [the term ueekata refers to the highest rank below Aji in the Ryukyuan aristocracy] An-ko)
sen.cmt: 毛其昌・美里親方安綱の読み不明。類推によります。松川（まちがー、現代地名は「まつがわ」）：http://okinawan.jp/minwa/minwa027.htm 親方ウェーカタ Ueekata: http://ryukyushimpo.jp/news/storyid-40355-storytopic-121.html 按司：http://www.weblio.jp/content/%E6%8C%89%E5%8F%B8

sen.j: 真鶴金・平良按司（父は高宮城親方朝功）
sen.e: Majirugani: Princess (Aji) Hirara (or Pisara or Taira) (her father was Takamiya-gusuku Ueekata Cho-ko)
sen.cmt: 平良は地名として、現代沖縄では「たいら」、宮古島方言では「ピサラ」（その日本語訳が「ひらら」）と読んだそうです。http://d.hatena.ne.jp/keyword/%CA%BF%CE%C9 高宮城親方朝功の読み不明。類推によります。 地名の読みは「たかみやぐすく」（沖縄出身者人名で「たかみやぎ」の読みも存在しています）：http://www.google.co.jp/search?hl=ja&q=%E6%B2%96%E7%B8%84%E3%80%80%E9%AB%98%E5%AE%AE%E5%9F%8E%E3%80%80%E3%81%9F%E3%81%8B%E3%81%BF%E3%82%84%E3%81%90%E3%81%99%E3%81%8F&aq=f&aqi=&aql=&oq=&gs_rfai= 朝功：http://www.google.co.jp/search?hl=ja&q=%E6%9C%9D%E5%8A%9F%E3%80%80%E3%81%A1%E3%82%87%E3%81%86%E3%81%93%E3%81%86%E3%80%80&aq=f&aqi=&aql=&oq=&gs_rfai=
